user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_init_mem_pools_:
```c
void
MHD_init_mem_pools_ (void)
{
#ifdef MHD_SC_PAGESIZE
  long result;
  result = sysconf (MHD_SC_PAGESIZE);
  if (-1 != result)
    MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t) result;
  else
    MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t) MHD_DEF_PAGE_SIZE_;
#elif defined(_WIN32)
  SYSTEM_INFO si;
  GetSystemInfo (&si);
  MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t) si.dwPageSize;
#else
  MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t) MHD_DEF_PAGE_SIZE_;
#endif /* _WIN32 */
  mhd_assert (0 == (MHD_sys_page_size_ % ALIGN_SIZE));
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Rule 21.17 concerns the use of string handling functions from <string.h> (e.g. memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn). The provided function MHD_init_mem_pools_ contains no calls to any of these functions or any other <string.h> APIs.

Line-by-line rationale:
- The sysconf(MHD_SC_PAGESIZE) call and its handling do not invoke any string functions; they obtain a system page size (long) and cast to size_t.
- The GetSystemInfo(&si) call on Windows is an OS API and does not involve string.h functions; assigning si.dwPageSize to MHD_sys_page_size_ is an integer assignment.
- The fallback assignment to MHD_DEF_PAGE_SIZE_ is a constant integer assignment.
- The mhd_assert checking alignment uses integer arithmetic and does not call string functions.

Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that could violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17, and no fragments need to be investigated for out-of-bounds accesses caused by <string.h> functions.
